posts.title: Environment-Specific EF Core Migrations with SQL Scripts
posts.description: EF Core migrations run the same code everywhere, but real apps need different seed data per environment. Here's a convention-based pattern that loads the right SQL script automatically.
posts.linkedInHook:
EF Core migrations are great for schema changes, but they run the same code everywhere. Real apps need different seed data per environment—demo users in dev, minimal data in staging, nothing in production.

The typical fix is wrapping everything in if (Environment.IsDevelopment()) checks. That gets ugly fast.

Here's a cleaner pattern: convention-based SQL scripts that load automatically based on environment. Script.dev.sql for dev, Script.prod.sql for production. The migration code stays simple.

posts.title: Upgrading Certbot to Wildcard Certificates
posts.description: My SSL setup worked great until I needed subdomains for a multi-tenant SaaS. One wildcard certificate covers them all—but Certbot's upgrade path has some gotchas.
posts.linkedInHook:
My SSL automation was humming along—until I needed subdomains for a multi-tenant SaaS app. Adding each one manually meant regenerating certs every time a client onboarded.

Solution: wildcard certificates. One cert covers *.domain.com.

But Certbot doesn't just upgrade in place. It creates a new cert with a -0001 suffix. And the rename command doesn't exist in older versions. Here's how to handle it cleanly.

posts.title: When AI Gives You Coaching Instead of Construction
posts.description: I asked ChatGPT for an algorithm. After fifteen minutes of 'you could consider...' I asked Gemini. Thirty seconds later I had an exponential decay accumulator. Here's what that taught me about AI tool selection.
posts.linkedInHook:
I asked ChatGPT for an algorithm to track customer outage patterns in real-time. Fifteen minutes of 'you could consider...' and 'one approach might be...' later, I still had nothing concrete.

Asked Gemini. Thirty seconds later I had an exponential decay accumulator—the same mathematical structure used in fraud detection and SLO burn-rates.

Then I asked ChatGPT to explain why this keeps happening. Its self-diagnosis was surprisingly honest.

posts.title: When Codecov Says 'Error' But Your Upload Succeeded
posts.description: Your CI shows green checkmarks. The upload returned 200. But Codecov reports 0 files and 0% coverage. Here's how to debug it—and why deleting your config file might be the fix.
posts.linkedInHook:
I keep running into this pattern with developer tooling: the 'improvements' that silently break things. This week it was Codecov. I added a config file to make things better, and it silently broke everything. The fix was deleting the config entirely.

It got me thinking about how often we add complexity thinking we're being thorough, when the simpler default would have worked fine.

posts.title: Blazor WASM Says 'Loading...' Forever: A .NET 10 Debugging Adventure
posts.description: Your Blazor app loads the HTML, shows the spinner, then... nothing. The console shows errors about '/0'. Here's the one-line fix for the WasmInlineBootConfig bug.
posts.linkedInHook:
Spent way too long debugging a Blazor WASM app that just showed 'Loading...' forever. The console errors pointed at '/0' which made no sense. Turns out there's a bug in .NET 10 preview where the boot config gets inlined wrong.

One line in the csproj fixed it. Documenting this so the next person doesn't lose their afternoon.

posts.title: Blazor WASM Debugging: What's That /_framework/debug Endpoint?
posts.description: You started a Blazor WebAssembly app and noticed a mysterious debug URL. Then Chrome wanted special flags. Then you saw 'Inspectable pages.' Here's what's actually happening.
posts.linkedInHook:
Started a new Blazor WASM project and got curious about a mysterious URL in the console: /_framework/debug. Chrome asked for special flags. Then I saw 'Inspectable pages' in a separate window.

Down the rabbit hole I went. Turns out there's a whole debugging proxy architecture that makes breakpoints work in WebAssembly. Pretty elegant once you understand what's happening.

posts.title: reCAPTCHA v3's Mobile Problem: Why Your Real Users Score Like Bots
posts.description: My wife scored 0.1 on reCAPTCHA. From our couch. On her phone. Here's what Google doesn't tell you about score thresholds and mobile users.
posts.linkedInHook:
My wife tried to use a contact form I built. She was on her phone, on our couch, clearly a real person. reCAPTCHA scored her 0.1—basically flagged as a bot.

Turns out the 0.5 threshold everyone recommends is way too aggressive for mobile users. Google doesn't exactly advertise this. Wrote up what I learned.

posts.title: SEO Oops Recovery: When You Accidentally Expose Everything
posts.description: Your admin dashboard is in Google. Your API key is in git history. That angry TODO comment is now public. Here's the emergency recovery guide.
posts.linkedInHook:
Every developer has that moment of cold sweat when they realize something that shouldn't be public is now indexed by Google. Or worse, that angry TODO comment in a commit message.

I've been there. Here's the recovery playbook I wish I'd had.

posts.title: Custom Error Pages: Turning 404s Into Teaching Moments
posts.description: Your visitors hit a 404. Do they see a cold 'Page Not Found' or a delightful learning opportunity? Here's how to make error pages that keep people engaged.
posts.linkedInHook:
Error pages are guaranteed traffic. Every site has them. Every visitor eventually sees one. So why do most of them look like the server is personally offended by your existence?

I decided to turn my 404s into tiny teaching moments. Here's the philosophy and implementation.

posts.title: Tailwind v4's Silent Breaking Change: The @source Directive
posts.description: You upgraded to Tailwind v4. Your build runs. Your CSS generates. Half your styles are missing. Welcome to the @source directive gotcha.
posts.linkedInHook:
Upgraded to Tailwind v4. Build ran. CSS generated. Half my styles were missing.

No errors. No warnings. Just... gone. Turns out v4 ignores your content array in tailwind.config.js. You need @source directives in CSS now. The migration path doesn't exactly scream this at you.

posts.title: Tailwind's Hidden Gotchas: Dynamic Classes and @layer
posts.description: Your dynamic class names aren't working. The CSS exists in your code but not in your output. Here's why Tailwind's JIT compiler is ignoring you and how to fix it.
posts.linkedInHook:
Tailwind's JIT compiler is amazing until it silently ignores your classes. Built a progress bar component with dynamic widths like `w-[${percent}%]`. None of them worked.

The JIT compiler only scans for complete class names in your source files. String concatenation breaks it. Here's what to do instead.

posts.title: Tailwind vs Bootstrap: The Paradigm Shift That Finally Made Sense
posts.description: You've been using Bootstrap for years. Then someone mentions Tailwind and suddenly you're supposed to write class names that look like inline styles from 2003. Here's why it's actually better.
posts.linkedInHook:
I resisted Tailwind for years. 'Why would I write class names that look like inline styles from 2003?'

Then I actually tried it. The mental shift from 'CSS describes components' to 'CSS describes design primitives' finally clicked. Here's what changed my mind.

posts.title: Events, Delegates, and Handlers: The Restaurant Analogy That Finally Made It Click
posts.description: Stop thinking about function pointers. Start thinking about bells and notifications. A restaurant analogy that makes C# events actually make sense.
posts.linkedInHook:
I've been copying EventCallback patterns in Blazor for months without really understanding them. Every explanation starts with 'a delegate is a type-safe function pointer' and my brain checks out.

Then I thought about it as restaurant bells and it finally clicked. The kitchen doesn't know who's listening. It just rings.

posts.title: RSS Feeds and Social Media Automation: Publishing Once, Sharing Everywhere
posts.description: You wrote a blog post. Now you need to share it on LinkedIn, Twitter, maybe a newsletter. Here's how to automate the boring part.
posts.linkedInHook:
I got tired of manually sharing blog posts to social media. So I went down the automation rabbit hole and ended up building a custom LinkedIn integration.

Was it faster than just posting manually? Absolutely not. But I learned OAuth, built something I control, and got a blog post out of it. That's a win in my book.

posts.title: GDPR Cookie Consent: The Essential-Only Shortcut
posts.description: Most cookie banners are obnoxious because they're trying to get consent for tracking. If you're not tracking anyone, the whole thing gets simpler.
posts.linkedInHook:
Cookie consent banners have become this obnoxious UX pattern that everyone hates. But here's the thing: they're obnoxious because they're trying to get consent for tracking.

If you're not tracking anyone, GDPR compliance gets surprisingly simple. Stop tracking people and the compliance problem solves itself.

posts.title: A Modest Proposal for AI Safety
posts.description: In which the author documents humanity's imminent obsolescence at the hands of our mechanical overlords. (Or does he?)
posts.linkedInHook:
With all the breathless AI discourse lately, I decided to write a modest proposal about our impending robotic overlords.

(Jonathan Swift would be proud. Or horrified. Hard to tell with that guy.)

posts.title: AI Won't Replace Developers, But...
posts.description: LinkedIn hot takes say AI replaces coders. After a year building production apps with AI assistance, here's what actually happens - and why expertise still matters.
posts.linkedInHook:
After a year building production apps with AI assistance, I have thoughts on the 'AI will replace developers' discourse.

Short version: AI is like having a brilliant but inexperienced junior developer who works at 3 AM. The value comes from knowing what to ask and how to evaluate the answers. Expertise matters more, not less.

posts.title: Testing Stripe Webhooks Without Tears: A Practical Guide to the Stripe CLI
posts.description: Setting up payment processing is stressful enough without wondering if your webhooks actually work. Here's how to test them locally before real money is on the line.
posts.linkedInHook:
Payment integration is stressful. 'It compiles' doesn't mean 'it won't silently fail when someone hands you their credit card.'

The Stripe CLI changed my life. You can test webhooks locally without deploying, watch real payloads flow through your system, and actually know if things work before real money is on the line.

posts.title: Google Search Console: The Step I Forgot (And Why My Site Was Invisible)
posts.description: You implemented all the SEO best practices. Meta tags, structured data, sitemaps—the works. Then you searched for your site and found... nothing. Here's the step nobody mentions.
posts.linkedInHook:
I wrote a whole post about SEO best practices. Meta tags, structured data, sitemaps—the works. Then I Googled my site. Nothing. It wasn't anywhere.

Turns out having perfect SEO markup means nothing if you never tell Google your site exists. The assumption that burned me and how I fixed it.

posts.title: Adding New Domains to Your Certbot + Cloudflare Setup
posts.description: You set up SSL automation once and it worked great. Then you added a new domain and hit every gotcha you'd forgotten about. Here's the checklist.
posts.linkedInHook:
Set up SSL automation months ago. Worked great. Then I added a new domain and hit every gotcha I'd forgotten about—API token permissions, first-time PFX export, file permissions for SCP.

Made myself a checklist so next time it takes 5 minutes instead of an hour of debugging.

posts.title: When Your Discord Bot Stops Hearing: A Debugging Odyssey
posts.description: How I spent days debugging a silent Discord bot, only to discover the application itself was corrupted—and Discord gave zero indication anything was wrong.
posts.linkedInHook:
Spent days debugging a Discord bot that just... stopped responding to commands. The code was fine. The logs were fine. Discord said everything was fine.

Turns out the application registration itself was corrupted. Discord gave zero indication anything was wrong. I had to delete and recreate it. Documenting this so the next person doesn't lose their sanity.

posts.title: SEO Demystified: How to Stop Being Invisible to Google
posts.description: You built a beautiful site but Google can't find it. Here's what actually matters for SEO—meta tags, structured data, sitemaps—explained for developers who'd rather write code than read marketing blogs.
posts.linkedInHook:
SEO guides are either 'just use WordPress plugins' or 47-page dissertations on keyword density algorithms. Neither helped me.

So I wrote the technical SEO guide I wish I'd had—what actually matters for meta tags, structured data, and sitemaps, explained for developers who'd rather write code than read marketing blogs.

posts.title: How This Blog Works: From Markdown to Web Pages
posts.description: No database, no CMS, no admin panel. Just Markdown files, a JSON registry, and a thin C# service. Here's exactly how this blog turns plain text into the page you're reading.
posts.linkedInHook:
When I built this blog, I wanted writing to feel like writing. Not clicking through menus, not fighting with rich text editors. Just open a file, type words, save.

No database. No CMS. Just Markdown files and a thin C# service. Here's exactly how it works.

posts.title: Building a Language Switcher That Actually Remembers: .NET Localization Part 2
posts.description: Your translations work, but users have to dig through browser settings to change languages. Let's build a dropdown that remembers their choice with cookies.
posts.linkedInHook:
Got localization working in .NET. Translations load correctly. Then realized users have to dig through browser settings to change languages, which is a terrible experience.

Built a dropdown that remembers their choice with cookies. Part 2 of making .NET localization actually work.

posts.title: The Case of the Missing Translations: Why Your .NET App Ignores Your Resource Files
posts.description: You set up localization, created the .resx files, it compiled... and then nothing happened. Here's why .NET silently ignores your translations and how to fix it.
posts.linkedInHook:
Set up .NET localization. Created the .resx files. It compiled. Nothing happened. The translations were just... ignored.

Turns out there are several ways .NET silently ignores your resource files. Naming conventions, folder structures, middleware order—all the gotchas I found the hard way.

posts.title: Code Coverage Without the Crying: A Practical Guide to Codecov
posts.description: Your test suite exists. It passes. But how much of your code does it actually test? Here's how to set up Codecov and stop living in denial.
posts.linkedInHook:
My test suite passed. I felt virtuous. Then I set up code coverage metrics and discovered I was testing about 23% of my actual code.

The other 77%? Living dangerously. Here's how to set up Codecov and stop living in denial.

posts.title: TLDRkseid: Building a Discord Bot That Summarizes Chaos
posts.description: I built a Discord bot to summarize hundreds of messages using OpenAI - then discovered that all Discord bots run as a single instance serving every server. Here's the journey.
posts.linkedInHook:
I was part of a Discord server that moved at the speed of chaos. Step away for lunch and you'd return to a novel's worth of missed context.

So I built a bot to summarize it. Then discovered something that floored me: Discord bots run as a single instance serving ALL servers. Your one process handles every server that invites it.

posts.title: Running AI On Your Own Computer: A Beginner's Guide to Ollama
posts.description: You can run real AI models locally - no internet, no fees, complete privacy. Here's how to get started with Ollama and why you'd want to.
posts.linkedInHook:
Here's something that surprises most people: you can run real AI models on your own computer. Not a stripped-down demo—actual LLMs running locally. No internet, no fees, no one watching what you ask.

I've been doing this for months. Here's how to get started with Ollama.

posts.title: What 1,290 ChatGPT Conversations Taught Me About My Own Thinking
posts.description: I exported two years of AI chats and used embeddings, clustering, and topic segmentation to find patterns. Here's what I learned - explained so anyone can understand.
posts.linkedInHook:
I've been using ChatGPT daily for two years. Then I realized I had no idea what was actually in those 1,290 conversations.

So I exported everything and analyzed it. Found I'd asked the same React questions fifteen times. My interests were more consistent than they felt. Turns out AI conversations are worth preserving—they form a detailed record of your thinking over time.

posts.title: Invisible Spam Protection: reCAPTCHA v3 in ASP.NET Core
posts.description: Adding invisible bot protection to a contact form with Google reCAPTCHA v3 and a honeypot field - no puzzles, no friction, no spam.
posts.linkedInHook:
Those 'click all the traffic lights' CAPTCHAs are terrible UX. reCAPTCHA v3 runs invisibly in the background, scoring users based on behavior instead of making them prove they're human.

Implemented it on a contact form with a honeypot field as backup. No puzzles, no friction, no spam so far.

posts.title: When Your AI Coding Assistant Gaslights You: A Performance Analysis Showdown
posts.description: I asked two AIs to help debug performance issues. One maintained context and found the root cause. The other kept saying 'likely your code does this' while looking at the actual code.
posts.linkedInHook:
Had a debugging session that perfectly captured the difference between AI pattern-matching and actual reasoning.

ChatGPT kept saying 'likely your code does this' about code I had literally just shown it. Claude traced the exact N+1 query path in thirty seconds. Using the word 'likely' about code you've been given is a red flag.

posts.title: SSL Automation with Let's Encrypt and Cloudflare
posts.description: Setting up free, automated SSL certificates for multiple domains using a Raspberry Pi, Certbot, and Cloudflare DNS.
posts.linkedInHook:
SSL certificates used to be this annual anxiety event. Let them expire and your site shows scary warnings.

Set up automated renewal with Let's Encrypt, Certbot, and a Raspberry Pi. Certificates renew every 90 days automatically. Haven't thought about SSL expiration in months.

posts.title: Adding Comments to a Blog with Giscus
posts.description: Using GitHub Discussions as a comment backend for a blog - no database, no spam, no cost.
posts.linkedInHook:
Wanted blog comments but didn't want to manage a database or fight spam. Giscus uses GitHub Discussions as the backend—commenters authenticate with GitHub, spam is someone else's problem, and it's completely free.

Perfect for a developer-focused blog.

posts.title: Email Authentication: SmarterASP + Cloudflare DNS
posts.description: A programmer's guide to SPF, DKIM, and DMARC - why email authentication exists and how to configure it when your DNS lives in Cloudflare.
posts.linkedInHook:
Email authentication (SPF, DKIM, DMARC) always felt like arcane magic to me. Why do these DNS records exist? What's the threat model?

Finally sat down and understood it. Turns out it's actually elegant once you see how the pieces fit together. Wrote up the explanation I wish I'd found.

posts.title: For Pisko
posts.description: Completing a novel, submitting to Novel90, and honoring the patient hound who inspired a character that watches across 500 years.
posts.linkedInHook:
Submitted my completed novel to Novel90 today.

It started as a tribute to my dog Pisko, who died before I began writing seriously. He became Taibhse—the spectral hound who watches across 500 years, hoping someone will finally get it right.

The difference between 'wanting to write' and 'being a writer' is finishing something.

posts.title: Resetting a Raspberry Pi Password via WSL
posts.description: When Windows won't mount ext4 and you've forgotten your Pi's password, WSL and disk images come to the rescue.
posts.linkedInHook:
Forgot my Raspberry Pi password. Windows can't mount ext4 drives natively. Didn't want to reflash the SD card and lose everything.

WSL to the rescue. Mount the drive in Linux, edit /etc/shadow, done. Quick reference for next time this inevitably happens.

posts.title: Writing Fast, Revising Forever
posts.description: What NaNoWriMo taught me about process: write fast to discover, revise slow to refine, and be ruthless about your patterns.
posts.linkedInHook:
Discovered something about my writing process this month: I write fast and messy (atmospheric, emotionally resonant, full of plot holes). Then I revise for structure and lose all the voice.

The solution isn't doing both at once. Write fast to discover. Revise slow to refine. Then marry the best of both.

posts.title: VS Code tasks.json for .NET Projects
posts.description: A reusable task configuration for building, running, testing, and deploying ASP.NET projects with Tailwind CSS.
posts.linkedInHook:
Finally organized my VS Code tasks.json for .NET projects. Build, run, test, deploy—all as keyboard shortcuts instead of typing commands.

Sharing the config in case anyone else wants a starting point.

posts.title: Celtic Gods Are Messy (And That's the Point)
posts.description: What 400+ Celtic deities taught me about moral complexity: forces that are neither good nor evil, but necessary and dangerous at once.
posts.linkedInHook:
Researching Celtic mythology for the novel. Found 400+ deities, most with contradictory stories across regions.

But that messiness is the point. These aren't good or evil forces—they're necessary and dangerous at once. Perfect framework for writing morally complex characters.

posts.title: The Stones That Remember
posts.description: A worldbuilding breakthrough: what if Irish stone circles weren't just settings, but a neural network across the land?
posts.linkedInHook:
Had a worldbuilding breakthrough for the novel. What if Irish stone circles weren't just settings, but a neural network across the land?

The stones remember. They pass information. They've been watching for thousands of years. Suddenly the setting became a character.

posts.title: Show, Don't Tell (Even When It Hurts)
posts.description: The brutal revision where I cut every explanation of my supernatural forces—and learned to trust my readers.
posts.linkedInHook:
Did a brutal revision pass where I cut every explanation of my supernatural forces. Every 'the fire was judgment incarnate' became just the fire doing things.

It hurt. But readers don't need explanations—they need experiences. Learning to trust them.

posts.title: Finding the Voice
posts.description: How I stopped writing chatty demons and learned to ground the supernatural in universal human experience.
posts.linkedInHook:
Early drafts of my novel had chatty demons explaining everything. It read like a supernatural Wikipedia.

The fix was grounding the strange in the universal. That burning feeling when you're certain you're right? That exhaustion of judgment without mercy? Those are human experiences—even when they're literally on fire.

posts.title: Electric Fuel Pump Conversion: John Deere 318
posts.description: Replacing a failing vacuum fuel pump with an electric pump, and the relay wiring needed to make it work safely with the oil pressure switch.
posts.linkedInHook:
Fixed a failing fuel pump on the John Deere 318 by converting from vacuum to electric. The relay wiring to make it work safely with the oil pressure switch was the interesting part.

Documenting for anyone else with an old Onan engine.

posts.title: How Black Ember Began (Or: From Video Game Avatar to Literary Fiction)
posts.description: Every novel has an origin story. Mine started with a superhero game avatar, transformed when my dog died, and became literary dark fantasy.
posts.linkedInHook:
Every novel has an origin story. Mine started with a superhero game avatar called Black Ember—an Irish vigilante, sort of Batman meets Constantine.

Then my dog died. And the avatar became a novel about self-condemnation, mercy, and a spectral hound who watches across centuries.

Your first concept is rarely your final story.
